text:
Conservative ministers and MPs ordered to remain in Commons until midnight tomorrow amid fears of Remain 'ambush vote' on Article 50 The Houses of Parliament Credit: Jonathan Brady/ Jonathan Brady Steven Swinford , Deputy Political Editor 30 January 2017 • 3:13pm 
C onservative ministers and MPs have been ordered to stay in the House of Commons until midnight tomorrow night amid fears of an “ambush” vote by pro-Remain MPs during the Article 50 debate. 
The Government has ordered there is a “running whip” tomorrow and into Wednesday for the two day debate on triggering Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty and starting the process of Brexit, sources have confirmed. 
This means that ministers and MPs will have to stay in the Commons until midnight when the House rises. 
Some Tory MPs are planning drinks parties in their Commons offices to fill the time. 
David Davis, the Exiting the European Union secretary, will kickstart the two day debate tomorrow afternoon ahead of the scheduled vote on Wednesday. 
Votes are virtually never taken during second readings of Government Bills with MPs on forced to go through the voting lobbies at the end of the debate. 
This means that the vote is meant to take place on Wednesday evening at 7pm. David Davis Credit: Steve Back / Barcroft Images/ Steve Back / Barcroft Images 
B ut Tory whips are on high alert for a sudden vote during the debate tomorrow to try to catch out the Government and vote down the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill . 
The Government cannot afford to allow MPs to delay the passage of the Bill because it needs to maximise the time of the Bill in the Lords to ensure that it receive royal assent by March 31. 
One source: “They fear there will be clever procedural way of coming at them and are worried they will get tripped up tomorrow. They are saying ‘we are going to have to think on our feet in case anything difficult happens’. 
“There is a fear that someone will dredge up a precedent which will say ‘actually there can be a vote on a device that has not been used for a hundred years’. 
"That is why everyone will be here even though it is meant to be talkfest." 
There were fears among Government whips of a division last Thursday when the Bill received its first reading 
One source said loyal Conservative MPs were asked to come back to the Commons just against SNP and Liberal Democrats and pro-EU MPs from the Conservative and Labour parties triggered a vote.
